Entries.default: The towering skeleton straightens his spine, and the sound of his bones shifting rattles around the cavern. A gilded sword rests strapped to his back, and in his hand, he grips a massive flail with a heavy skull for a striking head.
"How fares, brother?"
"Again now. Speak."
"Godschosen. 'Tis a blissin to meet ye if'n too a shame, as to walk here is to court with death."
"Been more 'an a middling lifewirth's since my flail's got bathed in bloody gore."

"Speak. Then perish. Less'n ye've a cause from Berath to fare here."

The Death Guard drags the spiked skull-head of his immense flail over the ground, gouging the stone at his feet. Then he hefts the flail's chain over his bony shoulders.
"I mean you no disturbance, but I'm on a mission of utmost importance."
"I couldn't be here if Berath didn't personally favor me."
"The reason I'm here? Why, townsfolk said this was the place to socialize."
"Threaten me again, you moldy sack of bones."
"Wait. I'll explain."

The skeleton stands still as death, magic billowing around him, burning up the air. For several moments he only stares. 

Then his teeth clack loudly, and he hefts the flail from his shoulders, swinging it just short of your throat.
"Abuttin yer next and last breath."
"A ghost ship sails the seas. I come to learn of Lucia Rivan so that I might end her haunting."
"Berath's high priest laments that your eulogy has been forgotten."
"I am not here for that which you protect, Death Guard of Berath."
"I learned of your history, and so sought you out - the great Yseyr, Aedyran chosen of Berath, and slayer of Lucia Rivan."
"Honestly... I was only exploring."
[Attack] "Let's get this over with."
The Death Guard seethes at the mention of Rivan's name. Rage, cold but violent, rattles up the skeleton's spine.
"CURSE HER SOUL TO NITHERIN TORTURE! Rivan wad've befouled Berath, wis a black pox on the eor that she whilom sought to vile ruin!"
"Aye. Stay yer death than, a will."
"Aye, be it two lifewirths, no Berathian priest hiv come to the sepulchers."
He studies you, eyes flickering silently. Then his teeth clack, and he drops the flail's skull down to crater the ground.
"Ye're learnt in the Berathian rites. Ye knaw how I serve my duty, even in death."
With a bone-popping nod, he drops the flail's skull down to crater the ground.
The Death Guard seethes at the mention of Rivan's name. Rage, cold but violent, rattles up the skeleton's spine.
He clacks a bone-shuddering step forward, then another. His otherworldly voice bellows an incantation to Berath, and the flames of his soul surge up, consuming the whole of his skeletal frame.
"What can you tell me about Lucia Rivan?"
"Can you tell me about the battle fought against the undead?"
"So you sacrificed yourself to guard this sacred weapon?"
"I must take the last stone tablet of your eulogy to the high priest of Berath."
"Whit're ye seekin to learn?"
"I've come to take Engoliero do Espirs."
"I've come to return your sacred charge."
"Rivan wis a Darcozzi paladin. She defied Berath, wielded a weapon nae meant for the hands of mortals."
"But Rivan wadn't keep dead. From sheer will an faith she ris a monster, able to breed an army of undead."
"Turned Death Guard, Rivan sailed with her undead army in her foulsome Fonferrus."
"A tracked the ship's comins an caught a regular trail. So a sailed to meet Rivan near the shallows of Dusken Isle."
"Than a waited. A far fog neared, despite the good winds. Rivan's ship crept from the mist."
"The winds died off. The waters calmed, an the ghost ship routed my ambush."
" 'Twis a slaughter. A wis mort wounded but fled with Berath's weapon, the Engoliero do Espirs."
"Aye, 'twas a harsh choice, but a made it. Wis willin to serve my deity by becomin' whit a hunted in her name."
"The weapon canna be allowed out in Eora. Needed to ward it for all time. But a canna keep it from the undead if a'm not undead myself."
"I could put that weapon to good use... for Berath."
[Attack] "I'll have that weapon for myself."
"Let me ask you about something else."
His pale bone fingers clench a tight grip on the weapon's hilt.
"Think ye're deservin, do ye? But in whitwey shoud a trust ye now?"
"I am one of Berath's chosen. Allow me to use it against death's transgressors."
"You want to see it unleashed against the enemies of Berath as much as I do."
"How will kith learn from the gods if we forever hide their truths in forgotten tombs?"
The Death Guard looms in silence. Light from the surrounding braziers warms the shade of his bones.
"Who else has been born twice of Berath, aside from me an you?"
"You can wield this weapon, aye. For a time. An first ye'll swear a blood oath to return it."
"Warn't ye one of Berath's own, a wad sunder ye to the bone. But yer nae wrong. Maybe the mort cold an endless nights hiv bled me of my right vengeance."

"A nae conne any more about the ways of kith, but a world without the gods' direction is doomed."

The towering skeleton cracks his head from side to side.
[Cut your hand.] "I'll return your charge, I swear."
[Pretend to cut your hand.] [Lie.] "I'll return it your charge, I swear."
"I'm not ready to make that oath."
He rattles his large skull.

"Now yer troth has been marked before Berath - an yer fate thisly sealed."

The ancient Death Guard hefts the sword toward you, beckoning you take it from his bony hands.
"Surely? A willn't make the offer again."
[Refuse the sword.] "So be it."
Magic flares from the blade he holds, but the skeleton says nothing.
"Aye, than. A'll allow it. Thae priests need to be keepin the sacrid rites of Berath alive."
"Thare it lies in my buirial grave."

"Takes a brave soul to relinquish such a virr an deadly weapon. A'm ready to resume wardin it, than."

He outstretches a cadaverous arm.
"If'n ye're ready to relinquish it."
[Relinquish the sword.] "It is yours to guard once more."
"Not quite yet."
"Berath be thanked." Yseyr accepts the heavy sword with a curt bow of his skull.

"Ye wadn't be gettin greedy, wad ye?"

The Death Guard regards you with a cutting suspicion.
"Farewell."
"Watcher."
"Than speak clear and true to whit eerant."
[Attack] "I warned you."
"Than ye'll die now, in the daurkness."
The skeleton stands rigid as death, the only movement a flicker of cunning in his eyes.
"You sure Berath's all right with you breaking the cycle of rebirth?"
"Aye. Or surely a wadn't be standin."
" 'Tis a dangerous ploy to break yer troth with me. Aye, so a know ye'll soon keep it."
"Who was she?"
"A conne her well." The Death Guard nods.
"Long 'n last! 'Tis a right-fine pleasure jawin' with someone who connes proper prose."

"Same to ye, my noble sir. 'Tis rare and seendle for a kinsman to cross my bruid this undead days. Whit a braw happenin. 

"But a still hiv a prestation to uphaud. Ye conne, aye?"

"Fye, I conne a thing or twelve bit dallying topside to shelter a stiff, unfeeling sliver o' being."

Aloth rolls his eyes as Iselmyr slips away again.
"A kindred soul can be a true balm. Bethank ye." He rolls his skull on his vertebrae, the sound like wood crackling in a fire.
"Right-fine, ye jolly eld bampot."
"Byous." He nods gravely.
"Hard to complain. All that beauty and fresh air out there. You should come outside with us sometime, it'd do you some good."
The fires flare hotter in the Death Guard's eyes.
"You know, cap, and this be just a thought, but you could always... not be doing that." He grins, his lip curling over a cockeyed tooth.
"A wairn ye - donna think ye can keep baith the weapon an yer life. Not forever."
"It's a good sword and all, but maybe it's best not to owe Berath any more favors."
"I'm inclined to go with Ed√©r's advice."
"Hey, that's great! Somebody else does Iselmyr's funny country-talk."
The Death Guard glowers menacingly.
"Let me ask you about something else."
"A wad aid any who hunt for Rivan. Aye. Stay yer death than, a will."
"With her Darcozzi sword, I can draw Rivan out to her final demise."
"A bid ye to take it." This fire in his eyes flickers as you retrieve the stone carving from within his sarcophagus.
"Eora canna be the same than whance a walked her. Old wisdom shoudna be foriver lost."
Twin fires flicker in the pits of his blackened eye sockets, burning with a deadly intent.
He studies you, eyes flickering silently. Then his teeth clack, and he drops the flail's skull down to crater the ground.
The Death Guard seethes at the mention of Rivan's name. Rage, cold but violent, rattles up the skeleton's spine.
"CURSE HER SOUL TO NITHERIN TORTURE! Rivan wad've befouled Berath, wis a black pox on the eor that she whilom sought to vile ruin!"
"A wad aid any who hunt for Rivan. Aye."

The skeleton stands still as death, magic billowing around him, burning up the air. For several moments he only stares. 

Then his teeth clack loudly, and he hefts the flail from his shoulders, swinging it just short of your throat.
"So tell me whit for the goddess wad send ye. Swithly."

The skeleton stands still as death, magic billowing around him, burning up the air. For several moments he only stares. 

Then his teeth clack loudly, and he hefts the flail from his shoulders, swinging it just short of your throat.
"Wiss me to laugh as a kill ye? Itherweys, speak true."

The skeleton stands still as death, magic billowing around him, burning up the air. For several moments he only stares. 

Then his teeth clack loudly, and he hefts the flail from his shoulders, swinging it just short of your throat.
"The dead feel no fear. Ye will come to be the same."
"A hunted for Rivan an the sword, from Vailia to the Deadfire. Hinderly, caught her. Slew her and took Berath's weapon for wardin."
"A tried to end them for good, but the battle turned against me."

"Came to the temple of Neketaka to be buried. But a couldn't leave the sword unwarded. So a begged Berath for anither chance to serve my cause.

"A refused to die."
"Oh, right. That's uh, that's my fault there. Shouldn't have brought it up."
"Thought I'd let you know, I gave your precious sword to Lucia Rivan in exchange for her ship."
"CURSE YE! FOUSOME BEAST! A'LL BASH YE TO NAE BUT BONE SPURS FOR BERATH'S REVENGE!"
He clacks a bone-shuddering step forward, then another. His otherworldly voice bellows an incantation to Berath, and the flames of his soul surge up, consuming the whole of his skeletal frame.
